Editorial
Case Report
Journal of Orthopaedic Case Reports 2013 April-June;3(2):32-34
The Incomplete Superficial Palmar Arch
1 2
Anneh Mohammad Gharravi*
Mohammad Reza
3 2
Gholami ,Daryoush Bijan Nejad
, Saeed Azandeh ,
Abstract
Introduction:
Case Report:
Conclusion:
Keywords: S
Superficial palmar arch (SPA) is dominant vascular structure in palm of hand. In
present study we described a case of Ulnar / Radiopalmar pattern of incomplete SPA in an Iranian
cadaver. When the SPA is complete, the superficial palmer branches of the radial artery contribute
to the ulnar artery. In incomplete type of SPA, there was no anastomosis between the ulnar and
radial arteries (UA, RA).
In the present case, the brachial artery divided into RA and UA at the cubital fossa.
There was no anastomosis between radial and ulnar arteries (RA, UA) in the palm of the hand. UA
gave three palmar digital arteries; proper palmar digital artery and two common palmar digital
arteries. RA gave proper palmar digital artery and arteria princeps pollicis.
Knowledge of anatomical variation of SPA is important for the hand surgical
interventions and this is a very rare variation which can be easily tested clinically by Allen's test
uperficial palmar arch, Ulnar artery, Radial artery
